member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper
member.summary: A collection of file system path analysis and manipulation functions.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.MakeRooted(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Generates an absolute path from a base path and another path.
member.param: An absolute path to use as the root if is relative. IMPORTANT: if basePath is a directory, it must end with a directory separator character or else it will be treated like a filename and discarded.
A relative or absolute path, that needs to be absolute.
member.exception: Thrown when the argument is not an absolute path.
member.returns: A normalized, absolute path. A path with relative parents (i.e. c:\temp\tmp\..\a.txt) will never be returned. Not necessarily canonical, in that the file casing of the path is not guaranteed to be consistent.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.MakeRelative(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: given the absolute location of a file, and a disc location, returns relative file path to that disk location.
member.param: The base path we want to relativize to. Must be absolute. Should not include a filename as the last segment will be interpreted as a directory.
The path we need to make relative to basePath. The path can be either absolute path or a relative path in which case it is relative to the base path
member.returns: The relative path (can be the full path when no relationship exists). If and are equivalent, the empty string is returned.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.EnsureNoTrailingSlash(System.String)
member.summary: Make sure there is no [unnececery] trailing directory separator.
member.returns: directory path without trailing slash

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.EnsureTrailingSlash(System.String)
member.summary: Make sure there is a trailing directory separator.
member.returns: directory path with trailing slash

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.IsInDirectoryCone(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Detects whether a given file falls within a given directory.
member.param: The absolute, normalized path to the directory.
The absolute, normalized path to the file.
member.returns: true if the given file falls within the given directory.
member.remarks: The current implementation of this method does NOT normalize the paths before the check.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.IsRooted(System.String)
member.summary: Tests a path to see if it is absolute or not. More reliable that Path.IsPathRooted.
member.returns: true if the path is rooted; false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.IsFolder(System.String)
member.summary: Check if path is a directory
member.returns: true if the path is a directory

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.GetCorrectCapitalization(System.IO.DirectoryInfo)
member.summary: Gets the correctly cased path for a given directory.
member.param: Directory to find the correct casing for.
member.returns: New directory with correctly cased path.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.IsPathValid(System.String)
member.summary: Verify a valid path
member.returns: True if a valid path

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.PathHelper.PathNeedsNormalization(System.String)
member.summary: A few fast checks that determine whether normalization of a path is warranted.
member.returns: true if normalization is likely needed; false if normalization doesn't appear to be needed.
member.remarks: In the interest of executing very fast (since this method is used in fast-or-slow-path checks) this method by no means is comprehensive, but it should catch the common causes for needing normalization.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.Indexing.IFileScanner
member.summary: Offers services to discover symbols defined in source files.
member.remarks: An implementing type should export this interface with the . Each instance of this interface should be prepared to deal with just one file type. If a single scanner advertises multiple , it should be prepared to identify which file type it is (if necessary) based solely on the content of the file and not the file name. If the file extension is an important distinguishing factor, use multiple instances of this interface, each advertising support for the various file extensions.

The set of workspace-relative paths to files that served as inputs to the construction of this context. This is *not* the set of files that would be read during execution of a build.

member.name: T:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.IFileContextProvider
member.summary: Offers services to discover contexts defined in source files.

remarks.para: An implementing type should export this interface using the .

Implementations should register contexts both for source files and outputs that may serve as inputs to other contexts. For example when a project B references project A, someone interested in initializing a language service for B may need to discover the context for A given A's primary output, which serves as an input for B.

member.name: P:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.Settings.IWorkspaceSettingsManager.OnWorkspaceSettingsChanged
member.summary: Event fire when a setting source (a file or in memory provider) changes. Listeners would need to reaquire (via GetAggregatedSettingsAsync) a new settings collection if they need to reflect the settings changes. The SettingsChangedEventArgs parameter can be used to narrow down the changes to a particular settings type and scopePath.

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.Settings.IWorkspaceSettingsManager.GetAggregatedSettings(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
the settings reader (note that when reading the settings hierarchy is already applied, the consumer should not diferentiate between where property is defined on use). The object returned by this property is immutable. when changes happen a new object will be create (and OnWorkspaceSettingsChanged fired).
will apply build in inheritance override rules(aka PerUser > PerWorkspace > PerMachine) and return the winning value for a named property, array or child settings
member.param: settings type (coresponding to the independent settings file name) Use SettingsTypes class constants
location under workspace we reqire the settings for. Note that because of hierarchical aggregation model different parts of the workspace tree will have different settings values.
member.returns: settings reader

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.Settings.IWorkspaceSettingsManager.GetSettings(System.String)
member.summary: "Parse" a single single settings file.
member.param: the full path to a settings file
member.returns: the settings object

member.name: M:Microsoft.VisualStudio.Workspace.Settings.IWorkspaceSettingsManager.GetPersistanceAsync(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Access the settings writer. All changes made are in memory untill the writer is released. note we will not lock any of the settings files untill commit. Also we are not going to lock the writer within the process. the individual actions (like individual property writes) will be protected. We would ensure a machine-wise locking via named event, which will protect against multiple VS instance writing at the same time, yet it would be possible if via other editor (notepad) or when settings file is shared on network, to have a conflicting writes. in this rare case comit may still fail.
member.param: if true the caller does not need to call commit at the end (note it is still possible to abort)
member.returns: the persistance instance
